com.sats

Class JDate

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.Date
      • com.sats.JDate
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Comparable<java.util.Date>

    public class JDate
extends java.util.Date
    Version:
    1.0
    JDate is a Date class, which provides contains all the useful functionality provided by the Date, Calender, DateFormat classes of Java Core library so that the Date manipulation code in the application becomes simpler Version 1.1 will have TimeZone related functions
    The class "is a" Date. Thus, it makes it easier for integration with any existing software projects.
    Please refer to the java.util.Date class specifications for the inherited methods
    Author:
    Satish Goriani
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      Constructor and Description
      JDate()
      Default constructor, initializes the DateFormat to default -> 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss", and Calender.

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      JDate add(int days)
      This method returns the date after adding the no of Days as passed in the argument
      JDate add(int field, int amount)
      This method returns the date after adding the "amount" to the "field" passed
      int get(int componentId)
      This method uses the Calender to return the component for a given date.
      JDate getDateComponent()
      This method removes the time component of a JDate and returns only the date component
      int getDaysBetween(JDate anotherDate)
      This gives the difference between "this" and another Date in "number of days"
      Important note:
      The function removes the 'time' component and uses only the 'date' component while computing the difference '03-Jan-2012 01:00 AM' and '02-Jan-2012 11:30 PM' will result in "1" as output.
      boolean isLeapYear()
      Checks if the date falls in a leap year
      JDate rolldown(int field)
      This calls an "subtract" with value for decrement as 1
      JDate rollup(int field)
      This calls an "add" with value for increment as 1
      JDate subtract(int days)
      This method returns the date after subtracting the no of days passed
      JDate subtract(int field, int amount)
      This method returns the date after subtracting the "amount" to the "field" passed
      java.lang.String toString() 
      java.lang.String toString(java.lang.String format)

      • JDate

        public JDate()
        Default constructor, initializes the DateFormat to default -> 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss", and Calender.

      • JDate

        public JDate(long date)
        Parameters:
        date - - the milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 GMT. Constructor which creates a date, using timestamp in millis.

      • JDate

        public JDate(java.lang.String text)
      throws java.text.ParseException
        Parameters:
        text - - text in the default format, i.e. yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss
        Throws:
        java.text.ParseException - - If the "text" format is invalid and can not be parsed Constructor which expects the date text to be sent in the default format

      • JDate

        public JDate(java.lang.String text,
     java.lang.String pattern)
      throws java.text.ParseException
        Parameters:
        text - - The text to be converted as JDate
        pattern - - Patterns (See the supported patterns in SimpleDateFormat Class
        Throws:
        java.text.ParseException - - For invalid input of text/ pattern Constructor which creates a date object based on the text passed and the corresponding pattern

      • get

        public int get(int componentId)
        This method uses the Calender to return the component for a given date. Following are examples of component ids.
        Calendar.YEAR
        Calender.MONTH
        Calender.WEEK_OF_MONTH
        Calendar.DAY_OF_MONTH etc. [Refer to the Calender class, for the entire list]
        Parameters:
        componentId - - Calender component of the date
        Returns:
        the component of the date requested for using Calender.get method.

      • add

        public JDate add(int field,
        int amount)
        This method returns the date after adding the "amount" to the "field" passed
        Parameters:
        field - - Field which is to be increased, e.g. Calender.HOUR, Calender.DATE, Calendar.YEAR etc.
        amount - - amount of increment
        Returns:
        The date after addition

      • add

        public JDate add(int days)
        This method returns the date after adding the no of Days as passed in the argument
        Parameters:
        days - - no of days of increment
        Returns:
        The date after addition

      • rollup

        public JDate rollup(int field)
        This calls an "add" with value for increment as 1
        Parameters:
        field - - Field which is to be increased, e.g. Calender.HOUR, Calender.DATE, Calendar.YEAR etc.
        Returns:
        Date after rolling up

      • subtract

        public JDate subtract(int field,
             int amount)
        This method returns the date after subtracting the "amount" to the "field" passed
        Parameters:
        field - - Field which is to be reduced, e.g. Calender.HOUR, Calender.DATE, Calendar.YEAR etc.
        amount - - amount of reduction
        Returns:
        The date after addition

        public JDate subtract(int days)
        This method returns the date after subtracting the no of days passed
        Parameters:
        days - - days of reduction
        Returns:
        The date after addition

      • rolldown

        public JDate rolldown(int field)
        This calls an "subtract" with value for decrement as 1
        Parameters:
        field - - Field which is to be decreased, e.g. Calender.HOUR, Calender.DATE, Calendar.YEAR etc.
        Returns:
        Date after rolling down

      • getDateComponent

        public JDate getDateComponent()
        This method removes the time component of a JDate and returns only the date component
        Returns:
        JDate - Date after taking off the time component

      • getDaysBetween

        public int getDaysBetween(JDate anotherDate)
        This gives the difference between "this" and another Date in "number of days"
        Important note:
        The function removes the 'time' component and uses only the 'date' component while computing the difference '03-Jan-2012 01:00 AM' and '02-Jan-2012 11:30 PM' will result in "1" as output.
        Parameters:
        anotherDate - - Date with which the difference needs to be measured.
        Returns:
        - Days between the current date and the date passed in the argument. Returns "negative" value if the date passed is greater.

      • isLeapYear

        public boolean isLeapYear()
        Checks if the date falls in a leap year
        Returns:
        true - if the date is in a leap year, false- if otherwise
